turns.speaker: TRIPLETTE
turns.text: Oh, no, listen, I don't want to take up too much of your time.

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: Don't you worry. We're just having a quiet Sunday at home.

turns.speaker: TRIPLETTE
turns.text: Well, I'm here putting together a show. It's a benefit really.

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: D.C.?  Tammany Hall?  He came there?

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: It's an appearance. It has nothing to do with support. I don't even like him.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Sue was trying to get hold of you.

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: Where the hell have you been?

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: Listen, we're suppose to sing on TV day after tomorrow. At the park...

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: He saw us at Tammany Hall.

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: The Hell he did. Look, I'll see you in the morning.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: Yes, sir. Like you to meet Opal.

turns.speaker: REESE
turns.text: Need to have you check these out before he goes on that Walker benefit.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: Sure thing. Put them here... I'll take them.

turns.speaker: REESE
turns.text: Thanks... I'll... go say hello to your mom.

turns.speaker: REESE
turns.text: Oh... Well... Have you heard from Barnett?

turns.speaker: REESE
turns.text: Let me know when you do, all right?

turns.speaker: OPAL
turns.text: Haven Hamilton is your father? Can you arrange an interview?

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: He got killed at a turkey shoot.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: Yes. I was in my Sophomore year at Harvard.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: Business School so I can run Haven's business.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: You go out in the woods and shoot targets -- Whoever shoots the most wins a live turkey

turns.speaker: OPAL
turns.text: How in the world did he get shot?

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: Some guy was drunk and hit him. Accident. Haven almost killed him.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: Sure do. Good friend of Haven's.

turns.speaker: OPAL
turns.text: Haven's not going to talk to me.

turns.speaker: NURSE
turns.text: HI. Look at those flowers. Did you grow those.

turns.speaker: GREEN
turns.text: Ester and me did;  My niece picked then. She's just here from California.

turns.speaker: NURSE
turns.text: That's good,  I've never seen anything so healthy.

turns.speaker: GREEN
turns.text: Yes, ma'am. How are you today?

turns.speaker: NURSE
turns.text: Didn't you get?... How are you?

turns.speaker: GREEN
turns.text: I'm fine. Can I go up?

turns.speaker: NURSE
turns.text: Let me see if I can get the doctor hold on one second.

turns.speaker: NURSE
turns.text: No. Mr. Green, I don't know how to tell you this -- your wire passed away -- I thought they'd called you at home.

turns.speaker: NURSE
turns.text: Your wire Ester - she passed away.

turns.speaker: KENNY
turns.text: Yes, sir. I need a room

turns.speaker: GREEN
turns.text: I think we can do that. Come in.

turns.speaker: GREEN
turns.text: I didn't think it would. She's calling herself L.A. Joan this- week. Last week it was Dakota. Guess if you have to change your name a state's as good as anything.

turns.speaker: GREEN
turns.text: My wife and I think so, but we're family. Your family's always good or bad depending on how you look at your family. What do you do, pick or sing?

turns.speaker: KENNY
turns.text: Oh... a little of both. Just thought I'd look around at Nashville for a while.

turns.speaker: GREEN
turns.text: When you run out or money, 'cause you will here, you can go sing at Bishop's Pub. They let you pass the hat. All these kids do that. Most every place doesn't want to bother with you.

turns.speaker: GREEN
turns.text: Well, don't be shy. I got the address here. Anytime you need it. Room's twenty-five dollar! a week and you can have breakfast with me if you like.

turns.speaker: KENNY
turns.text: Listen, do you know anything about cars?

turns.speaker: GREEN
turns.text: A little. What do you need?

turns.speaker: GREEN
turns.text: Sure... you're a fine boy, Ken, you really are.

turns.speaker: KENNY
turns.text: Okay... you get to sleep. I'll see you in the morning. Good night.

turns.speaker: L.A. JOAN
turns.text: Did you see who that was?

turns.speaker: GREEN
turns.text: Glad to see you. Ester'll be glad, too.

turns.speaker: GREEN
turns.text: She's been in the hospital two weeks yesterday.

turns.speaker: L.A. JOAN
turns.text: You know anything about the stations here?

turns.speaker: GREEN
turns.text: It's hard to say. Doctors thought she'd come home a week ago. All it was was appendix.

turns.speaker: L.A. JOAN
turns.text: All they got is advertisements. Just like L.A.

turns.speaker: GREEN
turns.text: Did an exploratory and according to them, she needed an overhaul.

turns.speaker: L.A. JOAN
turns.text: Well, I could use one, especially if I'm pregnant.

turns.speaker: L.A. JOAN
turns.text: I said, maybe I'll change my name again.

turns.speaker: GREEN
turns.text: I see... Well, those doctors are real miracle workers.

turns.speaker: L.A. JOAN
turns.text: But not unless Nashville really inspires me.

turns.speaker: GREEN
turns.text: Maybe you can look after me a little.

turns.speaker: KENNY
turns.text: A guy named Walker. Amazing person. He's developed a huge following.

turns.speaker: KENNY
turns.text: Well I've been following him around Just listening to him --He says he can really win -- I bet he can too - -

turns.speaker: JOAN
turns.text: I haven't gotten into politics yet. I'm still into music --except for you. You're into politics.

turns.speaker: KENNY
turns.text: Listen, your Aunt Ester just died. I'm... sorry... Listen, I really Feel bad now about last night...We had no...

turns.speaker: JOAN
turns.text: I'm in a hurry, gonna see this great group record at Woodland.

turns.speaker: KENNY
turns.text: I mean, Mr. Green was so nice to me. He took me in and...

turns.speaker: JOAN
turns.text: I don't really know what you're talking about.

turns.speaker: STAR
turns.text: Have you seen a woman about so high?

turns.speaker: STAR
turns.text: Hey, there - You seen my Winifred?

turns.speaker: STAR
turns.text: You got a place to stay?

turns.speaker: KENNY
turns.text: No. Probably stay at a motel tonight.

turns.speaker: KENNY
turns.text: Ah, hello. My name is Kenneth Fraser... And I'm here from Terre Haute, Indiana. Ah, listen ... somebody stole my handles.

turns.speaker: KENNY
turns.text: Oh, well, thanks. Ah, oh, maybe you know where...

turns.speaker: MOTHER
turns.text: I've been so worried, dear. where are you?

turns.speaker: MOTHER
turns.text: Oh, well, I knew that before you- even left. I told you, 'Kenny, that old Nash won't make it down the road.'  But you had to go.

turns.speaker: KENNY
turns.text: Well, I got to Nashville. That's pretty far.

turns.speaker: MOTHER
turns.text: How are you going to pay when you get sick?

turns.speaker: KENNY
turns.text: I'm in a rooming house with Mr. Green.

turns.speaker: MOTHER
turns.text: Green?  Not Owen Green. Owen Green embezzled money from your grandfather

turns.speaker: KENNY
turns.text: I don't know his first name.

turns.speaker: KENNY
turns.text: No. No, they're white. He's got a nice dog.

turns.speaker: MOTHER
turns.text: Worst time at year for dogs is when they get fungus.

turns.speaker: MOTHER
turns.text: He doesn1t have fungus, does he?

turns.speaker: MOTHER
turns.text: Well, you'll get it, skin as sensitive as yours.

turns.speaker: KENNY
turns.text: How do you know if they do?

turns.speaker: MOTHER
turns.text: Weather's been awful. All those bombs dropping. It changes our weather. Sure not like the good old days.

turns.speaker: MOTHER
turns.text: Your hair fell out? Just like your father. Weak hair.

turns.speaker: KENNY
turns.text: I want to get the dog off my bed.

turns.speaker: MOTHER
turns.text: But, I'll take some of that Nyquil... you know it puts you right to sleep no matter what's wrong, you go right off...

turns.speaker: KENNY
turns.text: Okay. I'll be talking to you.

turns.speaker: MOTHER
turns.text: Keep warm, dear. Let me hear from you.

turns.speaker: OPAL
turns.text: Have your children been deaf since birth?

turns.speaker: LINNEA
turns.text: Yes -- yes, they have. It was a real shock at first, especially since my daddy's a preacher, but Delbert and I have been blessed by their being here.

turns.speaker: LINNEA
turns.text: When I was little, in church.

turns.speaker: OPAL
turns.text: Isn't it unusual for you to be working with a black choir?

turns.speaker: OPAL
turns.text: Well, can you tell me why?

turns.speaker: OPAL
turns.text: How long have you been with them?

turns.speaker: LINNEA
turns.text: Just my church and my boys. We all had to go to school and learn hand talking. I just thank the Lord they can see.

turns.speaker: OPAL
turns.text: Do you ever do any writing?

turns.speaker: OPAL
turns.text: Are you a close friend of Haven's?

turns.speaker: LINNEA
turns.text: No, mostly his wife's. She's in Paris, France, right now. My husband Delbert is real friendly with him. Delbert's in law. Does work for him.

turns.speaker: LINNEA
turns.text: He's a member of our congregation.

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: Remember, about a month ago, your church choir cut a record?

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: Well, I met you that afternoon in the control room and we...

turns.speaker: LINNEA
turns.text: Oh, Tom, of course. What are you doing in Nashville?

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: I'd really like to see you.

turns.speaker: LINNEA
turns.text: Or course. You should come over to the house. The boys would love to meet you.

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: That's not quite what I had in mind.

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: Well, they removed my heart last week, but I'm doing fine except my nose fell off. Looks a little funny.

turns.speaker: LINNEA
turns.text: I don't know who you are.

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: What do you mean?  You said you wanted to see me.

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: Who is this, right?  I called you last night.

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: End of Church Street. Next to a grocery store.

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: I can't remember. In out/out in, something like that. Around eight.

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: You're really terrific, you know what I mean --LINNEA rolls over and faces him.

turns.speaker: LINNEA
turns.text: I have to go. He sighs.

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: When did you think it would happen?

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: I knew when I first met you.

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: Terrific!  Who was that black guy? A friend of yours?

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: Come on, you ever been attracted to a black guy?

turns.speaker: WADE
turns.text: I was in prison for twenty-eight years.

turns.speaker: WADE
turns.text: Just got out. Had me thirteen lawyers. Missed the electric chair twice. .. Been out three months. Are you heavy?

turns.speaker: WADE
turns.text: I'm forty-six. Do you like to go up or down?

turns.speaker: WADE
turns.text: High?  Do you ever get high? A walk on the wild side. Ever do dust?

turns.speaker: WADE
turns.text: All I need is fifteen minutes a night.

turns.speaker: WADE
turns.text: Sleep. That's all I need. Don't want to waste no time sleeping. You married?

turns.speaker: WADE
turns.text: Not me. Ain't never loved anybody. Ain't never been married. Won't either.

turns.speaker: WADE
turns.text: My mother. died in '72. They told me after. They said they couldn't find me before, so they told us after.

turns.speaker: WADE
turns.text: They said go see the chaplain.

turns.speaker: LINNEA
turns.text: I'm sorry but I have to go.

turns.speaker: WOMAN'S VOICE
turns.text: You sound different. Is that really you?

turns.speaker: WOMAN'S VOICE
turns.text: Can you make a rehearsal in the morning...?  Courtland wants to...

turns.speaker: MANAGER
turns.text: I can only give you fifty a week here and ten bucks for the benefit.

turns.speaker: MANAGER
turns.text: Are you sure you know what you're doing?

turns.speaker: MANAGER
turns.text: Well, there's a couple of girls in Printers Alley if you got any questions. I know I've seen that G- string stuff for sale someplace around.

turns.speaker: SUELEEN
turns.text: Don't you worry about Sueleen Gay.

turns.speaker: MANAGER
turns.text: That's for sure. At the airport - that's where it was. At the airport, there in one of those gift shops... Anyway, you better take a break.

turns.speaker: SUELEEN
turns.text: Thanks. You are just a wonderful person.

turns.speaker: TRIPLETTE
turns.text: He's pretty well known down here.

turns.speaker: TRIPLETTE
turns.text: Wednesday at the park. We've got a lot of names coming in...

turns.speaker: TRIPLETTE
turns.text: You're doing some recording here, aren't you?

turns.speaker: TRIPLETTE
turns.text: You don't know how pleased he'll be.

turns.speaker: NORMAN
turns.text: Pretty good. Sure was surprised to hear from you. You talk to Bill?

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: Not yet. Listen, Norman, I want...

turns.speaker: NORMAN
turns.text: They're looking all over for you. Do you have a copy of the album.

turns.speaker: NORMAN
turns.text: You know Bill is really mad at you.

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: We just got a gold record.

turns.speaker: OPAL
turns.text: Do they have a show to give it to you?

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: No  Hell, some secretary in New York just hands it to you. Only this one kept dropping it out of the box.

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: Dent it a little. Boy -- just she couldn1t even find it. She had a hamburger on her desk that looked three weeks old.

turns.speaker: OPAL
turns.text: How long have you been together?

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: Yeah, you bet. You're really terrific. You know what I mean?

turns.speaker: OPAL
turns.text: I'm gathering information about the characteristics of music people. I just finished a documentary on Gandi.

turns.speaker: OPAL
turns.text: The architect  His buildings are drippy. You know, like sand and castles. Then I got this assignment. They want to start in two weeks.

turns.speaker: TRIPLETTE
turns.text: What do you think of him?

turns.speaker: REESE
turns.text: Hal? Well, Hal and I have been friends for a long time.

turns.speaker: REESE
turns.text: We're connected by a relative. One time, one of his aunts married one of my uncles. That was a long time ago, though. How'd you come to work for him?

turns.speaker: TRIPLETTE
turns.text: Well, I really think he's got a chance.

turns.speaker: TRIPLETTE
turns.text: Oh yea -- There has never been a better time for something new.

turns.speaker: TRIPLETTE
turns.text: He is to a lot of people.

turns.speaker: REESE
turns.text: He was a good Judge, but that was a long time ago.

turns.speaker: TRIPLETTE
turns.text: You know, I'll bet you he makes it with a majority.

turns.speaker: REESE
turns.text: Well, I admire your optimism, and I just wondered if it was regional. You ever see any movie stars?

turns.speaker: REESE
turns.text: No kidding -- Wait till I tell Linnea. Who?

turns.speaker: REESE
turns.text: I never heard of him. Name somebody else.

turns.speaker: REESE
turns.text: You really do?  ~ God -- How come you know them?

turns.speaker: TRIPLETTE
turns.text: Oh, you meet them at parties and stuff.

turns.speaker: REESE
turns.text: I'll be damned. Boy, if you could get Ryan to say something about Hal Phillip Walker, wouldn't that be something?

turns.speaker: TRIPLETTE
turns.text: Well -- maybe. Let's see what happens here.

turns.speaker: WADE
turns.text: You want a ride into town?

turns.speaker: WADE
turns.text: Well, you just remember, if you can't kick front, kick back, 'cause at least you're kicking... Ten minutes, okay?

turns.speaker: SUELEEN
turns.text: No -- That's exercises. My coach says you have to do exercise because the vocal chords are muscle and need to be stretched. Every time you stretch them, the middle part sets stronger. That's the place where I sing.

turns.speaker: WADE
turns.text: You think I got any kind of a voice?

turns.speaker: WADE
turns.text: You think I should take lessons?

turns.speaker: SUELEEN
turns.text: If you're serious. Being serious is real important.

turns.speaker: SUELEEN
turns.text: Wade -- I've been working toward this audition for years.

turns.speaker: WADE
turns.text: Well, honey, I sure hope it comes your way then.

turns.speaker: TRIPLETTE
turns.text: I'm John Triplette. Excuse me. I got all caught up in looking at you. You'll be fine.

turns.speaker: TRIPLETTE
turns.text: Now this is to raise funds for someone who can help people who are less fortunate than yourself. The more you take off, you see, more money we can raise.

turns.speaker: TRIPLETTE
turns.text: I know that you are an artist and I am sure you are very religious.

turns.speaker: SUELEEN
turns.text: Don't you think they'd just love another song instead?

turns.speaker: TRIPLETTE
turns.text: Now, Sueleen, you know that's not what we talked about right here in this very room.

turns.speaker: MICKEY
turns.text: When you study the martial arts, they give out belts that come in different colors to signify what level you're at in your training. Am I correct on that point?

turns.speaker: MICKEY
turns.text: What was the color of Tim's belt?

turns.speaker: GRACE
turns.text: The style of fighting that Tim studied didn't believe in belts.

turns.speaker: MICKEY
turns.text: Is that a fact? Well then, Grace, could you tell us what form of martial arts it was that Tim was schooled in?

turns.speaker: GRACE
turns.text: Tim studied several styles, but his favorite was Jeet Kune Do.

turns.speaker: MICKEY
turns.text: Jeet Kune Do...Now I did some research on that form of fighting, and I found out that Jeet Kune Do was a style developed by Bruce Lee. Did you know that?

turns.speaker: GRACE
turns.text: Yes, I did. That's why Tim studied it. Because it was Bruce Lee's fighting style.

turns.speaker: MICKEY
turns.text: Now, while I freely admit total ignorance on the subject, I have heard of Bruce Lee. And I was under the impression that Bruce Lee was one of the, if not <u>the</u> greatest fighter in the history of martial arts.

turns.speaker: MICKEY
turns.text: So, I think it would be safe to say that anybody who studied the fighting style that Bruce Lee, arguably the greatest martial artist of all times, developed for nine years, that would be a fella who could defend himself. Would you describe Tim that way, Grace?

turns.speaker: MICKEY
turns.text: Point of fact, weren't Tim's hands registered as lethal weapons?

turns.speaker: MICKEY
turns.text: That means his hands are considered a weapon like a gun or a knife. Am I correct on that point?

turns.speaker: MICKEY
turns.text: Thank you. Grace, there is one other thing...

turns.speaker: MICKEY
turns.text: What kind of pies do you have?

turns.speaker: MABEL
turns.text: Apple, pecan, cherry, and key lime.

turns.speaker: MABEL
turns.text: The key lime is great, but it's an acquired taste.

turns.speaker: MICKEY
turns.text: I haven't had a key lime pie in ten years.

turns.speaker: MABEL
turns.text: When ya had it, did ya like it?

turns.speaker: MICKEY
turns.text: No, but that don't mean much. I was a completely different person ten years ago. Let's give key lime a day in court. And a large glass of milk.
